nodes.name: Action
nodes.description: "An action is a change which is brought about by a single agent, playing a role. The agent is the holder of some indended outcome of the action: an action is always intentional. The intention of the agent has usually corresponds with an expectation the intended outcome to be brought about: the agent believes in some expectation. Note that the intention might not correspond with the *actual* outcome of the action."

nodes.name: Creation
nodes.description: "An act which results in the creation of some entity/individual"

nodes.name: Reaction
nodes.description: "A reaction is an action that is (at least) performed by an agent that has observed some other action (this is an intensional view): Action <-> Reaction"

nodes.name: Agent
nodes.description: "It is a holder for propositional attitudes"

nodes.name: Organisation
nodes.description: "An organisation is a group of other organisations or persons which acts 'as one'. An organisation can be both formal (i.e. created by law or decree) or informal."

nodes.name: Person
nodes.description: "A person is an individual agent. Usually associated with 'human being'."

nodes.name: Artifact
nodes.description: "A physical object created by some person to fulfill a particular purpose"

nodes.name: Collaborative_Plan
nodes.description: "A collaborative plan is a plan which is shared (and executed) between at least two agents a and b."

nodes.name: Transaction
nodes.description: "A transaction is an exchange or interaction between at least two agents a and b. Consists of two actions A and B where a is the actor of action A and the recipient of action B, and vice versa. Usually these actions are performed concurrently, but these may also be done consequently."

nodes.name: Natural_Object
nodes.description: "A natural object is an object not created by man."

nodes.name: Personal_Plan
nodes.description: "A personal plan is a plan which is held (and can be executed) by at most one agent."

nodes.name: Plan
nodes.description: "A plan is a structure of multiple other plans or actions. These can be both sequential or concurrent. Usually a plan is referred to in the context of the intention to act of some agent, however when executed the plan itself comes into effect."

nodes.name: Trade
nodes.description: "A trade is an exchange of some things between two agents a and b. Consists of two actions A and B where a is the actor of action A and the recipient of action B, and vice versa. Usually these actions are performed concurrently, but these may also be done consequently. The ownership of the things being traded is the requirement/result pair for each action."

nodes.name: Speech_Act
nodes.description: "A speech act (or illocutionary act) creates some propositional attitude which qualifies an expression (which by default is mediated through some medium). The actor of the speech act is the utterer of the atitude (NB cannot be expressed in OWL DL)."

nodes.name: Argument
nodes.description: "An argument is a reason that is expressed through some medium"

nodes.name: Assertion
nodes.description: "The assertion is subject to a fit between words and world, in Searle's terms. It's propositional content can be true of false. If it is inconsistent with other assertions, beliefs, observations, it may come to be considered false."

nodes.name: Lie
nodes.description: "An assertion that is inconsistent with the beliefs of the speaker. It is *intentionally* false."

nodes.name: Assumption
nodes.description: "proposes something that usually is the case, although there is no specific evidence that it is true in this particular case"

nodes.name: Belief
nodes.description: "Someting an agent 'believes in', i.e. holds as true"

nodes.name: Cause
nodes.description: "A cause is an epistemic role played by something which is the outcome of a (chain) of processes"

nodes.name: Communicated_Attitude
nodes.description: "A communictated attitude is a propositional attitude involved in an act of communication."

nodes.name: Declaration
nodes.description: "Searle: the successful performance of a declaration is sufficient to bring about the fit between words and world, to make the propositional content true. In other words, if there is an inconsistency between the declaration and assertions, beliefs, or observations, it is not the declaration that is false. True of definitions and norms, and several other performative statements by legislators."

nodes.name: Promise
nodes.description: "A promise is a communicated attitude about some future action or state"

nodes.name: Statement_In_Writing
nodes.description: "Not to be confused with the actual writing/document itself, which is the medium of the statement."

nodes.name: Desire
nodes.description: "A feeling of wanting"

nodes.name: Document
nodes.description: "A Document bears some (and only) expression(s) stated by some statement in writing."

nodes.name: Evaluative_Attitude
nodes.description: "An evaluative attitude expresses e.g. a judgment. The proposition qualified by the evaluative attitude is comparable to something else."

nodes.name: Evaluative_Proposition
nodes.description: "Some thing which is evaluatively qualified, i.e. an evaluation applies to the proposition, the proposition is judged. The proposition is comparable to some other proposition."

nodes.name: Evidence
nodes.description: "Observation and/or statement, used as a backing for a belief. Evidence is the role of observation which is qualified by some belief."

nodes.name: Exception
nodes.description: "An exception is something that is excluded from a general statement or does not follow a rule. In LKIF rules, an exception is a rule which has an exception relation to another rule (cf. Deliverable 1.1)"

nodes.name: Expectation
nodes.description: "An expectation is a predictive belief held on purely logical grounds, i.e. not based on direct external evidence, like an observation or a statement by another agent. It is also often characterized as a "belief about the future", but this isn't very helpful since one may also hold expectations about the (yet unknown) past. The theory of evolution is for instance a fertile ground for predictions about the existence of past species, and therefore at the same a predictor of future observations."

nodes.name: Expression
nodes.description: "An expression is a proposition beared by some medium, e.g. a document, and is stated by some communicated attitude"

nodes.name: Fact
nodes.description: "A fact is a proposition (about something) which is (commonly) agreed upon to hold as true: it has some backing in evidence"

nodes.name: Intention
nodes.description: "Intention is where the agent expects certain consequences of his or her actions and desires those consequences to occur. This concept must be related to qualification and preference in some way."

nodes.name: Medium
nodes.description: "A medium is a bearer of expressions, i.e. externalised propositions. Propositions become expressions once they are externalised through some medium."

nodes.name: Observation
nodes.description: "An observation is the role played by some proposition believed to be true or false through observation of an agent."

nodes.name: Problem
nodes.description: "NOTE: This currently cannot be expressed: OWL DL does not support negation of properties. The definition will be further elaborated once OWL 1.1 is supported by development tools."

nodes.name: Surprise
nodes.description: "A surprise is an observation that deviates from an expectation."

nodes.name: Proposition
nodes.description: "NOTE: In previous versions of this ontology, this class was called 'Qualified'. In lieu of the separation between Proposition and Propositional_Attitude, the intended meaning of that class has been moved to 'Evaluative_Proposition'"

nodes.name: Propositional_Attitude
nodes.description: "A propositional attitude connects a person (the holder of the attitude) to some proposition, in fact it expresses some qualification over the proposition. Distinguishing a proposition from the propositional content expressed by it is necessary when properties relating to the thing expressed and properties of the expression itself must be distinguished. For LKIF the distinction between Belief, Intention, Qualification, and Observation is relevant. The distinction between belief/expectation, intention, and observation is relevant for i.a. establishing mens rea (guilty mind). The distinction between beliefs (expressing the content of the mind of an agent) and statements (expressing the content of an act of communication by an agent) is classical."

nodes.name: Qualification
nodes.description: "A qualification expresses e.g. a judgment. The thing qualified by the qualification is comparable to something else."

nodes.name: Qualified
nodes.description: "Something that is qualified by some qualification"

nodes.name: Reason
nodes.description: "Teleological counterpart of cause"

nodes.name: Act_of_Law
nodes.description: "Act of law: a public act by a legislative body which creates an expression with legal status; the legal status depends on the jurisdiction of the legislative body."

nodes.name: Assignment
nodes.description: "A public act that attributes a power to perform a public act to a public body."

nodes.name: Association
nodes.description: "A voluntary association (also sometimes called an unincorporated association, or just an association) is a group of individuals who voluntarily enter into an agreement to form a body (or organization) to accomplish a purpose."

nodes.name: Co-operative
nodes.description: "An autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social, and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly-owned and democratically-controlled enterprise."

nodes.name: Company
nodes.description: "A company refers to a legal entity formed which has a separate legal identity from its members, and is ordinarily incorporated to undertake commercial business. Although some jurisdictions refer to unincorporated entities as companies, in most jurisdictions the term refers only to incorporated entities. "

nodes.name: Limited_Company
nodes.description: "A limited company is a corporation whose liability is limited by law"

nodes.name: Public_Limited_Company
nodes.description: "Similar to the US corporation, offers several advantages over trading as sole trader."

nodes.name: Corporation
nodes.description: "A corporation is a legal entity which, while being composed of natural persons, exists completely separately from them. This separation gives the corporation unique powers which other legal entities lack. "

nodes.name: Foundation
nodes.description: "A kind of (philanthropic) organization, set up as a legal entity either by individuals or institutions, with the purpose of distributing grants to support causes in line with the goals of the foundation"

nodes.name: Incorporated
nodes.description: "An organisation formed into a legal corporation"

nodes.name: Decision
nodes.description: "NOTE: Cannot express that the 'promised' act corresponds to the act qualified by the statement in writing"

nodes.name: Delegation
nodes.description: "Delegate: entrust a task or responsibility to some other person"

nodes.name: Legal_Person
nodes.description:
"A legal entity is a natural person or a legal construct through which the law allows a group of natural persons to act as if it were a single composite individual for certain purposes. The most common purposes are lawsuits, property ownership, and contracts. Sometimes referred to as corporate personhood or legal personality, this concept allows for easy conduct of business by having ownership, lawsuits, and agreements under the name of the legal entity instead of the several names of the people making up the entity.

A legal entity is not necessarily distinct from the natural persons of which it is composed. Most legal entities are simply amalgamations of the persons that make it up for convenience's sake. A legal entity that does have a separate existence from its members is called a company or corporation. This distinction gives the corporation its unique perpetual succession privilege and is usually also the source of the limited liability of corporate members. Some other legal entities also enjoy limited liability of members, but not on account of separate existence (Source: Wikipedia.org)"

nodes.name: Private_Legal_Person
nodes.description: "A legal person as defined in private law"

nodes.name: Public_Body
nodes.description: "A public body or body created by an act of law to serve a public interest"

nodes.name: Legal_Speech_Act
nodes.description: "A legal speech act creates some propositional attitude towards a legal expression."

nodes.name: Legislative_Body
nodes.description: "A legislature is a type of (representative) deliberative assembly with the power to adopt laws."

nodes.name: Mandate
nodes.description: "Mandate: give (someone) authority to act in a certain way"

nodes.name: Natural_Person
nodes.description: "A natural person is a human being perceptible through the senses and subject to physical laws, as opposed to an artificial person, i.e., an organization that the law treats for some purposes as if it were a person distinct from its members or owner."

nodes.name: Society
nodes.description: "An organized group of people associated together for religious, benevolent, cultural, scientific, political, patriotic, or other purposes."

nodes.name: Public_Act
nodes.description: "A public act is an act by some Person or Organisation which creates (at least) a communicated attitude (and thereby an expression)"

nodes.name: Legal_Role
nodes.description: "A legal role is a role played in a legal context. Legal role players can be both Agents and other 'things'"

nodes.name: Social_Legal_Role
nodes.description: "A social legal role is played by some agent in the context of legal activities."

nodes.name: Professional_Legal_Role
nodes.description: "A professional legal role is a legal profession of some person, examples: lawyer, judge etc."

nodes.name: Atom
nodes.description: "An atom is the most basic (undivisible) part of an LKIF rule (cf. Deliverable 1.1)"

nodes.name: Negated_Atom
nodes.description: "A negated atom is the negation of some other atom (cf. Deliverable 1.1)"

nodes.name: Rule
nodes.description: "An LKIF rule, based on swrl:Impl"

nodes.name: Valid_Rule
nodes.description: "A valid LKIF rule"

nodes.name: Abstract_Entity
nodes.description:
"An abstract concept is a concept which does not (necessarily) have a referent in either the physical or the mental world.   

Abstract entities are (proto)mathematical, formal entities, entities which have a purely formal, logical or mathematical meaning.

As all concepts are abstractions, one may argue that a separate abstract world is difficult to see. In common-sense, a circle has more properties and is less abstract than in mathematics. Even mathematicians marvel about the fact their pure abstractions enable us to predict very concrete things. However, we are not directly concerned with these mappings. The most important is that common-sense knows about a (small) number of proto-mathematical concepts, such as collections, sequences and count-numbers (positive integers). We know also about geometric simplifications such as line, circle, square, cube, etc. These common sense notions might even be the real roots of our mathematics. However, these kind of semi-formal abstractions do not play a very central role in law, and therefore LRI-Core is thinly populated with abstract classes."

nodes.name: Occurrence
nodes.description: "A consequence of our clear separation of ontology from models of situations (occurrences), is well exemplified in the two ways we look at time and space. Things happen against the canvas of space and time. This 3D canvas moving in time (or whatever metaphor) allows us to index instances of objects and processes. Time and space provide positions in time and space for objects. Positions are in general modeled in some mereological framework. However, the objects and processes as classes have time and space properties in a different way. Space occupied by an object is its inherent property of size or extension. This property was for Descartes even the critical one that separated mental (not: abstract) objects from physical ones. Processes occupy (consume) time; they take some duration. This time resource is inversely related to the consumption of energy. This distinction between position and extension is also made in various other ontologies. However, this distinction is easily obscured by the fact that the extension of an object can also be used as a reference for location. An object can be in another object. In fact, any physical object can be used as a spatial and even temporal referent. This does not refute our view that locations are occurrences. To be precise: extension is an inherent, necessary property of a physical object or process; its location is an accidental one."

nodes.name: Spatio_Temporal_Occurrence
nodes.description: "An occurrence in space-time"

nodes.name: Physical_Entity
nodes.description:
"The physical world evolves around two main classes: physical objects and processes.

In lkif-core, the physical world evolves around two main classes: physical objects and processes. Objects are pieces of matter, while matter is typed by substances. Objects have mass, extension, viz. form and aggregation state (which limits form). Objects are the specification of the notion that matter, and in particular solid objects, is what makes the physical world relatively stable and observable. We define (physical) situations in the first place by the arrangement of physical objects (entities)."

nodes.name: Part
nodes.description: "A part is a part_of some whole"

nodes.name: Whole
nodes.description: "A whole has at least some part"

nodes.name: Composition
nodes.description: "A composition has multiple parts, the components should meet"

nodes.name: Pair
nodes.description: "A composition of exactly two parts"

nodes.name: Action_Power
nodes.description: "An action-power consists in a generic power to produce a legal effect through an action determining it. Also called Subjections"

nodes.name: Allowed
nodes.description: "See normatively qualified. Alternative labels: permitted, sanctioned, let, licensed."

nodes.name: Allowed_And_Disallowed
nodes.description: "Something which is both allowed and disallowed through some norm"

nodes.name: Obliged
nodes.description: "Is allowed by an Obligation, i.e. the alternative is strictly_worse according to the Obligation. Alternative labels: directed, commanded."

nodes.name: Strictly_Allowed
nodes.description: "Loose end."

nodes.name: Belief_In_Violation
nodes.description: "A belief in some violation"

nodes.name: Code
nodes.description: "A legal code bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legislative body. It cannot bear expressions which are not uttered by a legislative body."

nodes.name: Code_of_Conduct
nodes.description: "a code outlining the responsibilities of or best practice for an individual or organisation, such as a set of principles of good corporate behaviour adopted by a business\"

nodes.name: Contract
nodes.description: "A contract bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some natural person or legal person. It cannot bear expressions which are uttered by a different kind of agent."

nodes.name: Custom
nodes.description: "The collective memory of some group of agents, i.e. propositions beared by custom are shared (i.e. held) by all members of the group"

nodes.name: Customary_Law
nodes.description: "In law, custom, or customary law consists of established patterns of behaviour that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting."

nodes.name: Declarative_Power
nodes.description: "We say that j has the declarative power to realize A to mean that if j declares A, then it is legally valid that A. For example, if x has the declarative power to terminate y’s obligation toward x to do then if x declares that y’s obligation toward x finishes, then it is legally valid that this obligation finishes."

nodes.name: Decree
nodes.description: "The word decree is often used as a derogative term for any authoritarian decision"

nodes.name: Definitional_Expression
nodes.description: "A definition in a legal context (for example “x means y” or “by x it is meant y”);"

nodes.name: Directive
nodes.description: "Examples are European Union directive, a legislative act of the European Union and Directives, used by United States Government agencies (particularly the Department of Defense) to convey policies, responsibilities, and procedures."

nodes.name: Disallowed
nodes.description: "See Qualified. Alternative labels: violation, prohibited, forbidden"

nodes.name: Strictly_Disallowed
nodes.description: "Loose end."

nodes.name: Disallowed_Intention
nodes.description: "The propositional content (i.e. that which is intended) of the intention is disallowed. Interesting concept for establishing mens rea (guilty mind), although 'disallowed' is a weaker qualification than criminal. Note the distinction between purposely committing a crime and knowingly committing a crime. The crime committed does not have to match the crime intended for establishing intent!"

nodes.name: Enabling_Power
nodes.description: "An enabling power is used in cases where the law aims at enabling some agent to produce an effect in a particular way."

nodes.name: Potestative_Right
nodes.description:
"A potestative right is an enabling power which is meant to benefit the holder of the power. For example, if some animal y does not 
belong to anybody, then x has the potestative-right to start x’s ownership of the animal,  by capturing y."

nodes.name: Evaluative_Expression
nodes.description: "A legal evaluative expression asserts that something is good or bad, is a value to be optimised or an evil to be minimised (for example “human dignity is value”, “participation ought to be promoted”);"

nodes.name: Exclusionary_Right
nodes.description:
"An exclusionary right concerns the prohibition against performing certain inferences (against reasoning in certain ways), or 
against using certain kinds of premises for certain purposes, in the interest of a particular person. This is especially the case with anti-discrimination rules."

nodes.name: Existential_Expression
nodes.description: "Establishes or terminates the existence of a legal entity (for example “the company ceases to exist”);"

nodes.name: Hohfeldian_Power
nodes.description: "A hohfeldian power covers any action which determines a legal effect."

nodes.name: Immunity
nodes.description: "Also called Disabilities"

nodes.name: International_Agreement
nodes.description: "An agreement entered into by actors in international law, namely states and international organizations. "

nodes.name: Non-binding_International_Agreement
nodes.description: "Some international agreement that is not binding under international law"

nodes.name: Resolution
nodes.description: "A resolution is a written motion adopted by a deliberative body. The substance of the resolution can be anything that can normally be proposed as a motion."

nodes.name: Treaty
nodes.description: "A treaty is a binding agreement under international law entered into by actors in international law, namely states and international organizations. Treaties are called by several names: treaties, international agreements, protocols, covenants, conventions, exchanges of letters, exchanges of notes, etc."

nodes.name: International_Arbitration
nodes.description: "International Arbitration is the established method today for resolving disputes between parties to international commercial agreements. As with arbitration generally, it is a creature of contract, i.e., the parties' decision to submit any disputes to private adjudication by one or more arbitrators appointed in accordance with rules the parties themselves have agreed to adopt, usually by including a provision for the same in their contract. The practice of international arbitration has developed so as to allow parties from different legal and cultural backgrounds to resolve their disputes, generally without the formalities of their underlying legal systems."

nodes.name: Legal_Doctrine
nodes.description: "Legal doctrine is a framework, set of rules, procedural steps, or test, often established through precedent in the common law, through which judgments can be determined in a given legal cas"

nodes.name: Legal_Document
nodes.description: "A legal document is a document bearing norms or normative statements. By virtue of this definition the norm-as-propositional-attitude is reified as norm-as proposition. In other words, the norm being expressed through the legal source is an expression of the propositional attitude."

nodes.name: Regulation
nodes.description: "A regulation bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legislative body. It cannot bear expressions which are not uttered by a legislative body."

nodes.name: Statute
nodes.description: "A statute bears one or more norms, all of which are uttered by some legal person. It cannot bear expressions which are uttered by a different kind of agent."

nodes.name: Legal_Expression
nodes.description: "Legal expressions are created by  some legal speech act and qualified by a communicated attitude"

nodes.name: Potestative_Expression
nodes.description: "Attributes a power to some agent (for example “a worker has the power to terminate his work contract”);"

nodes.name: Qualificatory_Expression
nodes.description: "Ascribes a legal role to a person or an object (for example,  “x is a citizen”, “x is an intellectual work”, “x is a technical invention”);"

nodes.name: Legal_Source
nodes.description: "A legal source is a source for legal statements, both norms and legal expressions. In a sense it is literally a 'source' of law"

nodes.name: Precedent
nodes.description: "In law, a precedent or authority is a legal case establishing a principle or rule that a court may need to adopt when deciding subsequent cases with similar issues or facts. The term may also refer to the collective body of case law that a court should consider when interpreting the law. When a precedent establishes an important legal principle, or represents new or changed law on a particular issue, that precedent is often known as a landmark decision."

nodes.name: Proclamation
nodes.description: "A proclamation (Lat. proclamare, to make public by announcement) is an official declaration."

nodes.name: Soft_Law
nodes.description: "The term "soft law" refers to quasi-legal instruments which do not have any binding force, or whose binding force is somewhat "weaker" than the binding force of traditional law, often referred to as "hard law", in this context. The term "soft law" initially appeared in the area of international law, but more recently it has been transferred to other branches of law."

nodes.name: Liability_Right
nodes.description: "A liability right expresses some right to act that brings with it some liability to perform another (compensating) act. For instance, if some k performs the permitted action A, then k will have to perform another action B for the benefit of j."

nodes.name: Liberty_Right
nodes.description: "When, for the benefit of a person, this person is both permitted to perform and to omit an action – that is, when the action is facultative – we can say that he or she has a liberty right with regard to that action."

nodes.name: Mandatory_Precedent
nodes.description: "In law, a binding precedent (also mandatory precedent or binding authority) is a precedent which must be followed by all lower courts. It is usually created by the decision of a higher court, such as the House of Lords in the United Kingdom. Binding precedent relies on the legal principle of stare decisis."

nodes.name: Norm
nodes.description: "A norm is a kind of Qualification. A qualification which normatively qualifies some thing (i.e. some normatively qualified): i.e. a qualification which allows or disallows some thing."

nodes.name: Permission
nodes.description: "Permission allows propositions, to which therefore the predication Allowed applies. The thing(s) allowed is/are a subset of the thing(s) qualified by the permission. If S then P(A) means that S is qualified and S and A is allowed."

nodes.name: Right
nodes.description: "A right is the legal or moral entitlement to do or refrain from doing something or to obtain or refrain from obtaining an action, thing or recogition in civil society."

nodes.name: Normatively_Qualified
nodes.description: "Some thing which is qualified (allowed, disallowed) by a norm, i.e. a norm applies to the thing. Taking the principle of deontic choice to mean that the utterer of a normative statement intends to influence choices made by the addressee of the statement, the qualified thing should is comparable to some alternative. Note that Qualified does not partition into Allowed and Disallowed. Firstly, things can be Allowed by one Norm and Disallowed by another one. Secondly, the logical complement of the thing allowed by a permission is qualified (as worse or equal than the thing allowed), but neither allowed nor disallowed."

nodes.name: Obligation
nodes.description: "See prohibition"

nodes.name: Obligative_Right
nodes.description: "Directed obligative ought-to-do are also called obligative rights. k has the obligative  right that j does A iff it is obligatory, toward k, that j does A. An example of obligative  right is “it is obligatory, toward Mary, that Tom pays 1,000 euro to John”"

nodes.name: Observation_of_Violation
nodes.description: "An observation of a violation, i.e. of something that is Disallowed."

nodes.name: Prohibition
nodes.description: "Prohibition obliges/allows thing(s), to which therefore the predication Obliged applies, and disallows thing(s), to which therefore the predication Disallowed applies. The union of the thing(s) allowed and the thing(s) disallowed is qualified by the prohibition. The things allowed and disallowed by the prohibition are disjoint (and completely partition the space of things qualified). If S then O(A) means that S is qualified, S and A is obliged/allowed, and S and not A is disallowed. If S then F(A) means that S is qualified, S and A is disallowed, and S and not A is obliged/allowed. The difference between Obligation and Prohibition is in which part of the partition of the qualified space is explicitly described by the normative statement. Alternative label: directive"

nodes.name: Permissive_Right
nodes.description: "The  negation of a directed obligation is a directed permission. However, it counts as a right,  namely, a permissive right, only when such negation is aimed at benefitting the author of  the permitted action. "

nodes.name: Persuasive_Precedent
nodes.description: "In law, a persuasive precedent or advisory precedent is a precedent that need not be followed under the legal principle of stare decisis, but is nevertheless followed. Sources of persuasive precedent include the obiter dicta in the judgment of a court whose judgment would otherwise be binding, and the judgments of courts in other jurisdictions where the facts and/or legal system are similar to the case at hand. If a superior court adopts a persuasive precedent, it may become binding in the jurisdiction."

nodes.name: Mental_Process
nodes.description: "A mental, i.e. non-physical, process that has no physical effects. Examples are (human) thought and reasoning."

nodes.name: Continuation
nodes.description: "The continuation of a change, once initiated"

nodes.name: Initiation
nodes.description: "The initation of a change"

nodes.name: Termination
nodes.description: "The termination of a change."

nodes.name: Place
nodes.description: "A place is a spatio-temporal-occurrence"

nodes.name: Absolute_Place
nodes.description: "An absolute place is defined without reference to other places."

nodes.name: Comprehensive_Place
nodes.description: "A place is comprehensive if it always covers every place (and thus also every location-complex) and every object."

nodes.name: Location_Complex
nodes.description: "A location complex only overlaps its own parts (OWL 1.1)"

nodes.name: Relative_Place
nodes.description: "A relative place is defined by some reference to some object/thing"

nodes.name: Subjective_Entity
nodes.description: "A subjective entity is ontologically subjective, i.e. its existence is relative to an observer, that attributes its properties to some other entity, given a context.  "

nodes.name: Function
nodes.description: "The use or purpose of some object as used in some context."

nodes.name: Organisation_Role
nodes.description: "A role which has a meaning in the context of an organisation: i.e. the role defines a 'position' within sthe structure of roles within an organisation"

nodes.name: Person_Role
nodes.description: "A role played by some person (i.e. not an organisation)"

nodes.name: Role
nodes.description: "A role is a specification of default behavior and accompanying expectations of the thing 'playing' the role. Similar to actors in a theater who play roles, but are not the roles. Example: student."

nodes.name: Social_Role
nodes.description: "played_by all (action:Agent and (action:actor_in some (action:Action and (plays some expression:Expectation))))"

nodes.name: Application
nodes.description: "When a local act applies in the local legal system normative supra-ordered such as when a region applies an EU directive or a decree it applies the normative contant in some act"

nodes.name: Application_Date
nodes.description: "The date when a modification is applied to the destination legislative document. The date can be instantaneous, in the future or in the past. Normally this date coincides with the date of efficacy of the text in which the modification takes place."

nodes.name: Application_Interval
nodes.description: "This is the interval during which a normative document, or fragment, produces the consequences that the normative provision establishes."

nodes.name: Delivery_Date
nodes.description: "The date when the competent authorities finalise the document by affixing their signatures to it (e.g. promulgation by the president, signature by the queen etc.) This is the date shown on the document itself: it is an objective element and clearly identifyable."

nodes.name: Deregulation
nodes.description: "When a part of some primary legislative source is delegated to some secondary legislative source (e.g. from act to regulation). "

nodes.name: Dynamic_Temporal_Entity
nodes.description: "A dynamic temporal entity represents the norm in its evolution over time."

nodes.name: Efficacy_Interval
nodes.description: "The period during which a normative fragment may be either operative or inoperative, by explicit provision of the document itself. The document is said to be in a period of operation, or enforceability or efficacy, when it may or must be applied or enforced."

nodes.name: In_Force_Interval
nodes.description: "The period during which a normative fragment belongs to the normative system. The period of force for each fragment may change over time as a function of the modifications the document goes through."

nodes.name: Efficacy_Modification
nodes.description: "Modifies the efficacy period of some norm"

nodes.name: Prorogation_Efficacy
nodes.description: "Prorogation of entry into force, but applied to the efficacy of some norm"

nodes.name: Retroactivity
nodes.description: "When the efficacy or a partial efficacy starts before the entry into force of the document"

nodes.name: Suspension
nodes.description: "When a part of an act or some provisions are suspended in coming to be operative for a period or indefinately"

nodes.name: End_in_Force
nodes.description: "When an act states the end of the period of enactment, and includes an implicit repealing of the text."

nodes.name: Enter_in_Force_Date
nodes.description: "The date when a dnormative document becomes law and enters the legal system for the first time. This is the moment in the doucment's history starting from which the document can be amended, its applicability assessed, and its manner of producing an effect determined."

nodes.name: Existence_Date
nodes.description: "The date when the formal act by which a legislative body freezes the document into its final form, it is the time when the document can be said to have begun its existence."

nodes.name: Extension
nodes.description: "Extends the scope of normative content to some particular jurisdiction"

nodes.name: In_Force_Modification
nodes.description: "Modifies the period of being in force of some norm"

nodes.name: Prorogation_in_Force
nodes.description: "Prorogation of the date of enactment of some normative content. The 'life' of the act is lengthened with respect to some previous end of enactment modification."

nodes.name: Interpretation
nodes.description: "Modification of the interpretation of normative content by the author or some superior actor"

nodes.name: Modification
nodes.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"

nodes.name: Semantic_Annotation
nodes.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"

nodes.name: Temporal_Modification
nodes.description: "Modifies the efficacy or being in force of some norm"

nodes.name: Textual_Modification
nodes.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"

nodes.name: Modification_of_Meaning
nodes.description: "A modification that changes the meaning of some provision without changing its literal text"

nodes.name: Modification_of_Term
nodes.description: "Modification of the term specified by some procedural deadline."

nodes.name: Variation
nodes.description: "Modification by paraphrasing"

nodes.name: Modification_of_Scope
nodes.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"

nodes.name: Modification_of_System
nodes.description: "See ESTRELLA deliverable 3.2"

nodes.name: Ratification
nodes.description: "When an international treaty is ratified by local parliament in order to include it in the local legal system. The same thing happens when each local parliament ratifies bilateral or multilateral agreements."

nodes.name: Remaking
nodes.description: "When an act is completely rewritten in a new way but the topic remains the same."

nodes.name: Transposition
nodes.description: "Interpretation in context of the European Union"

nodes.name: Publication_Date
nodes.description: "The date when the normative document is published in the official journal designated as the source for making all such documents public and legal."

nodes.name: Relocation
nodes.description: "Moving some part of the text to some other place within the same document"

nodes.name: Repeal
nodes.description: "Removal of some part of text or the entire act from the legal system."

nodes.name: Static_Temporal_Entity
nodes.description: "A static temporal entity captures a single moment in the norm's life that is fixed over time."

nodes.name: Substitution
nodes.description: "Substitution of a part or entire act or annex"

nodes.name: Moment
nodes.description: "A moment is an atomic period of time, i.e. it cannot be divided into other parts"

nodes.name: Interval
nodes.description: "An interval is a composition of multiple periods of time."

nodes.name: Pair_Of_Periods
nodes.description: "A pair of two time periods"
